Material used.Description: Human embryonic kidney cells (HEK293E) and human epithelial cancer (HeLa) were maintained at 37°C under humidified conditions and 5% CO₂. Cells were grown in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM) and supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS).

Readout description.Result Description: PD-linked PINK1 mutation Q126P compromises Parkin translocation to mitochondria and mitochondrial clearance, with reduced binding to Parkin
PD-linked PINK1 mutation L347P compromises Parkin translocation to mitochondria and mitochondrial clearance, with reduced binding to Parkin
PD-linked PINK1 mutation W437X compromises Parkin translocation to mitochondria and mitochondrial clearance, with reduced binding to Parkin
PD-associated Parkin mutation K161N shows similar binding to PINK1 WT as wild-type Parkin, with no effect on binding efficiency
PD-associated Parkin mutation K211N shows similar binding to PINK1 WT as wild-type Parkin, with no effect on binding efficiency
PD-associated Parkin mutation T240R shows similar binding to PINK1 WT as wild-type Parkin, with no effect on binding efficiency
PD-associated Parkin mutation R275W shows similar binding to PINK1 WT as wild-type Parkin, with no effect on binding efficiency
PD-associated Parkin mutation G430D shows similar binding to PINK1 WT as wild-type Parkin, with no effect on binding efficiency

Biological replicates.Description: short exposures of the respective western blots from four independent experiments were used to assess pixel intensities

Basic positive control.Description: FLAG-Parkin was co-expressed together with PINK1-V5 in HEK293E cells.

Basic negative control.Description: Respective empty vectors were used as negative controls.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Statistical significance was assessed by two-tailed paired student’s-t-test.

Material used.Description: HEK293E cells were co-transfected with indicated FLAG-Parkin and PINK1-V5 constructs for 48 h, washed once with PBS and lysed in cold lysis buffer.

Readout description.Result Description: PINK1 Q126P shows strongly reduced binding to Parkin WT compared to PINK1 WT
PINK1 L347P shows strongly reduced binding to Parkin WT compared to PINK1 WT
PINK1 W437X shows strongly reduced binding to Parkin WT compared to PINK1 WT

Biological replicates.Description: Quantification of (co)-immunoprecipitations was performed by densitrometric analyses using ImageJ software from four independent experiments.

Basic positive control.Description: FLAG-Parkin was co-expressed together with PINK1-V5 in HEK293E cells.

Basic negative control.Description: Respective empty vectors were used as negative controls.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Statistical significance was assessed by two-tailed paired student’s-t-test.

Material used.Description: HeLa cells and Parkin WT inducible SH-SY5Y cells were pretreated with 100 nM bafilomycin A1 for 16 h. Dissipation of mitochondrial membrane potential was achieved with 10 mM (for HeLa) or 20 mM (for SH-SY5Y) CCCP for indicated time points.

Readout description.Result Description: PINK1 Q126P significantly impairs Parkin translocation to mitochondria after 2 h CCCP treatment, leading to reduced perinuclear clustering of damaged mitochondria. At 24 h CCCP, mitochondrial clearance is substantially blocked, with residual mitochondrial markers detected via TOM20 staining. PINK1 Q126P shows reduced mitochondrial localization compared to WT, with increased cytosolic distribution.

PINK1 L347P fails to efficiently recruit Parkin to mitochondria after mitochondrial depolarization, resulting in minimal Parkin co-localization with TOM20-positive mitochondria. Mitochondrial degradation is severely compromised at 24 h, with intact mitochondrial structures visible. Similar to Q126P, L347P exhibits impaired mitochondrial stabilization, remaining predominantly in the cytosol.

PINK1 W437X shows enhanced initial mitochondrial localization even without CCCP treatment, but fails to promote Parkin translocation upon damage. Mitochondria remain dispersed and are not efficiently cleared by 24 h CCCP, indicating a defect in mitophagy initiation despite altered localization. The mutation disrupts Parkin recruitment, likely due to reduced PINK1-Parkin binding.

Biological replicates.Description: Representative images from at least three independent experiments; ≥200 Parkin-positive cells scored per experiment.

Basic positive control.Description: Cells transfected with PINK1 WT and EGFP-Parkin show robust Parkin mitochondrial translocation and mitochondrial clearance after CCCP treatment.

Basic negative control.Description: PINK1 siRNA-transfected cells or empty vector controls show no Parkin translocation and incomplete mitochondrial degradation.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Quantification of Parkin co-localization and residual mitochondria via ImageJ, with significance assessed by student’s t-test (**p < 0.005, ***p < 0.0005).
